question: Don't forget the checkee. Can't produce playees without checkees.
answer: You can count on me-o, you dirty young man.

question: "Hold me, touch me', 'hold me, touch me', 'hold me, touch me', where is 'hold me, touch me'? Ahhh ... here we are. 'Hold me, touch me.'" Darling!
answer: Hold me, touch me.

question: Devil woman.
answer: Finder's keepers.

question: Here I come, ready or not.
answer: What's the matter? Papa no want to play with baby?

question: Ohhhhhh. Come to Papa. Come to Papa do.
answer: To the victor go the spoils.

question: I'm gonna get you. Ohhhhhhhh.
answer: Meeow. Meeow. I wonder where Old Tom is tonight? Meeow.

question: Rowrrr. Aieeeeyiyiyiyiyi,
answer: Oh, Bialy, Bialy, darling, did I hurt you?

question: My hand. My hand. I can't turn my hand.
answer: Don't worry. I'll kiss it and make it well.

question: Enough. It's better. Please, Lambchop, it's better. Stop. You're hurting it again.
answer: How do you do. I mean ... Excuse me ... I mean ...

question: You mean ooops, don't you? Say ooops and get out.
answer: I'll wait in the hall ...

question: Oooooooops!
answer: Ooooooops.

question: I can't abide a peeping Tom. There's one in the apartment just opposite my bedroom window. I swear that man NEVER takes his field glasses off me for a minute. Feeling better? Good. Let's fool around. Now, I'll be the innocent little milk maid and you'll be the naughty stable boy. Oh, this milk is so heavy. I'll never reach the house. Help. Will someone help me?
answer: Wait. Wait. We can't play today. I have too many appointments.

question: We can't play today?
answer: Thursday. Thursday. We'll play Thursday. We'll play the Contessa and the chauffeur.

question: Oh, the best one.
answer: Until Thursday, then, Contessa Mio.

question: Oh, Bialy, please, just a little. Just a little.
answer: All right. All right.

question: So, the Count hired you this morning, Rudolfo ... Watch the road ... Watch the road.
answer: I can't take my eyes off you. How can I drive when you drive me mad. Mad.

question: Rudolfo, you dirty pig! Pull over.
answer: Good. That's enough. We'll do the rest on Thursday. That's a good girl. It's always such fun to see you. Until Thursday, then, you bawdy wench.

question: Oooh. I love it. Hold me, touch me.
answer: Thursday. I'll see you Thursday.

question: And we'll finish playing the Contessa and Rudolfo.
answer: Good. Yes. Thursday.

question: And after that we'll play the Abduction and cruel rape of Lucretia ... And I'll play Lucretia. Oh, Thursday. Will Thursday ever come?
answer: Like clockwork.

question: I shall count the minutes.
answer: Goodbye, my angel ... My angel! Hey, touch me ... wait! Hey, uh ... Lucretia, Lucretia!

question: Yes???
answer: Oh, Angelcake, you forgot to give me the check. Can't produce a play without money, ha, ha, ha.

question: Of course, the check, I had it with me all the time. I don't know what's happening to me. I must be getting old. Is it all right? I made it out to cash. You didn't tell me the name of the play.
answer: Oh, it's fine. Fine. Good. Good. Bye. Bye.

question: Til Thursday, my Darling, I shall count the minutes. Ta. Ta.
answer: Ta. Ta. Murderer! Thief! How can you take the last penny out of a man's pocket? Oh Lord, hear my plea. Destroy him. He maketh a blight on the land. Nnnnn. That hurt. I'll have to make another call. Have you been there all this time? And did you see and hear everything? Then what do you have to say for yourself?

question: Ta. Ta. Murderer! Thief! How can you take the last penny out of a man's pocket? Oh Lord, hear my plea. Destroy him. He maketh a blight on the land. Nnnnn. That hurt. I'll have to make another call. Have you been there all this time? And did you see and hear everything? Then what do you have to say for yourself?
answer: Uh ... uh ... ooooooops?

question: Who are you? What do you want? Why are you loitering in my hallway? Speak, dummy, speak! Why don't you speak?
answer: Scared. Can't talk.

question: All right. Get a hold of yourself. Take a deep breath, let it out slowly and tell me who you are.
answer: I'm Leo Bloom, I'm an accountant, I'm from Whitehall and Marks, I was sent here to do your books and I'm terribly sorry I caught you with the old lady.

question: "Caught you with the old lady." Come in, Mr. Tact. So you're an accountant, eh?
answer: Yes sir.

question: Then account for yourself! Do you believe in God? Do you believe in gold? Why are you looking up old lady's dresses? Bit of a pervert, eh?
answer: Sir, I ...

question: Never mind. Never mind. Do the books. They're in that desk over there. Top drawer. How dare you condemn me without knowing all the facts.
answer: But sir, I'm not condem ...

question: Shut up. I'm having a rhetorical conversation. How humiliating. Max Bialystock. Max Bialystock. You know who I used to be? Max Bialystock! The King of Broadway! Six shows running at once. Lunch at Delmonico's. Two hundred dollar suits. Look at me. Look at me now! I'm wearing a cardboard belt! I used to have thousands of investors begging, pleading, to put their money into a Max Bialystock production. Look at my investors now. Voila! Hundreds of little old ladies stopping off at Max Bialystock's office to grab a last thrill on the way to the cemetery. You have exactly ten seconds to change that disgusting look of pity into one of enormous respect. One ... Two ... Do the books! Do the books!
answer: Yes, sir. Thank you.

question: Window's so filthy, can't tell if it's day or night out there. Look at that. A white Rolls Royce. That's it baby, when you got it, flaunt it.
answer: Koff, koff ... ahem, ahem ... harrumph ...

question: I assume you are making those cartoon noises to attract my attention. Am I correct in my assumption, you fish-faced enemy of the people? I have hurt your feelings. Good, what is it?
answer: Sir, may I speak to you for a minute?

question: Go! You have fifty-eight seconds.
answer: Well, sir, it seems ...

question: You have forty-eight seconds left. Hurry. Hurry.
answer: In looking at your books, I've discovered that ...

question: Twenty-eight seconds, hurry, hurry, you're using up your time.
answer: Mr. Bialystock, I cannot function under these conditions. You're making me extremely nervous.

question: What is that? A handkerchief?
answer: It's nothing ... nothing.

question: If it's nothing, why can't I see it?
answer: My blanket. Give me my blue blanket.

question: Here, don't panic.
answer: I'm sorry ... I don't like people touching my blue blanket. It's not important. It's a minor compulsion. I can deal with it if I want to. It's just that I've had it ever since I was a baby and ... and ... I find it very comforting.

question: They come here. They all come here. How do they find me?
answer: Mr. Bialystock ...

question: Yes, Prince Mishkin, what can we do for you?
answer: This is hardly a time for levity. I've discovered a serious error here in the accounts of your last play.

question: Where? What?
answer: According to the backer's list you raised $60,000. But the show you produced only cost fifty-eight thousand. There's two thousand dollars unaccounted for.

question: I went to a Turkish bath, who cares? The show was a flop. What difference does it make?
answer: It makes a great deal of difference. That's fraud. If they found out, you could go to prison.

question: Why should they find out? It's only two thousand dollars, Bloom, do me a favor, move a few decimal points around. You can do it. You're an accountant. The word 'count' is part of your title.
answer: But that's cheating!

question: It's not cheating ... It's charity. Bloom, look at me ... look at me! I'm drowning. Other men sail through life. Bialystock has struck a reef. Bloom, I'm going under. I am being sunk by a society that demands success, when all I can offer is failure. Bloom, I'm reaching out to you. Don't send me to jail. Help! Help!
answer: Oh dear, oh dear, oh dear, oh dear.

question: Help!
answer: All right. I'll do it. I'll do it.

question: Thank you, Bloom. I knew I could con you.
answer: Oh, it's all right ... wha?

question: Nothing. Nothing. Do it. Do it.
answer: Now let's see, two thousand dollars. That isn't much. I'm sure I can hide it somewhere. After all, the department of internal revenue isn't interested in a show that flopped.

question: Yes. Right. Good thinking. You figure it out. I'm tired. I'm gonna take a little nap. Wake me if there's a fire.
answer: Now let's see, if we add these figures, we get ... Heh, heh, heh, amazing. It's absolutely amazing. But under the right circumstances, a producer could make more money with a flop than he could with a hit. Yes. Yes. It's quite possible. If he were certain the show would fail, a man could make a fortune.

question: Yes???
answer: Yes, what?

question: What you were saying. Keep talking.
answer: What was I saying?

question: You were saying that under the right circumstances, a producer could make more money with a flop than he could with a hit.
answer: Yes, it's quite possible.

question: You keep saying that, but you don't tell me how. How could a producer make more money with a flop than with a hit?
answer: It's simply a matter of creative accounting. Let us assume, just for the moment, that you are a dishonest man.

question: Assume away!
answer: Well, it's very easy. You simply raise more money than you really need.

question: What do you mean?
answer: You've done it yourself, only you did it on a very small scale.

question: What did I do?
answer: You raised two thousand more than you needed to produce your last play.

question: So what? What did it get me? I'm wearing a cardboard belt.
answer: Ahhhhhh! But that's where you made your error. You didn't go all the way. You see, if you were really a bold criminal, you could have raised a million.

question: But the play only cost $60,000 to produce.
answer: Exactly. And how long did it run?

question: One night.
answer: See? You could have raised a million dollars, put on a sixty thousand dollar flop and kept the rest.

question: But what if the play was a hit?
answer: Oh, you'd go to jail. If the play were a hit, you'd have to pay off the backers, and with so many backers there could never be enough profits to go around, get it?

question: Aha, aha, aha, aha, aha, aha!! So, in order for the scheme to work, we'd have to find a sure fire flop.
answer: What scheme?

question: What scheme? Your scheme, you bloody little genius.
answer: Oh, no. No. No. I meant no scheme. I merely posed a little, academic accounting theory. It's just a thought.

question: Bloom, worlds are turned on such thoughts! Don't you see, Bloom. Darling, Bloom, glorious Bloom, it's so simple. Step one Step four "Ah, Rio, Rio by the seao, meo, myo, meo ... "
answer: Mr. Bialystock. No. Wait. Please. You're holding me too tight. I'm an honest man. You don't understand.

question: No, Bloom, you don't understand. This is fate, this is destiny. There's no avoiding it.
answer: Mr. Bialystock, not more than five minutes ago, against my better judgment, I doctored your books. That, sir, is the ultimate extent of my criminal life.

question: OOOOOHH! OOOOOHH! OOOOOHH! OOOOOHH! I WANT THAT MONEY!
answer: Oh, I fell on my keys. I've got to get out of here.

question: You miserable, cowardly, wretched little caterpillar. Don't you ever want to become a butterfly? Don't you want to spread your wings and flap your way to glory?
answer: You're going to jump on me. You're going to jump on me. I know you're going to jump on me -- like Nero jumped on Poppea.

question: What???
answer: Poppea. She was his wife. And she was unfaithful to him. So he got mad and he jumped on her. Up and down, up and down, until he squashed her like a bug. Please don't jump on me.

question: I'm not going to jump on you!
answer: Aaaaaaaaaa!

question: Will you get a hold on yourself.
answer: Don't touch me! Don't touch me!

question: What are you afraid of? I'm not going to hurt you! What's the matter with you?
answer: I'm hysterical. I'm having hysterics. I'm hysterical. I can't stop. When I get like this, I can't stop. I'm hysterical. I'm wet! I'm wet! I'm hysterical and I'm wet! I'm in pain! And I'm wet! And I'm still hysterical! No! No! Don't hit. It doesn't help. It only increases my sense of danger.

question: What can I do? What can I do? You're getting me hysterical.
answer: Go away from me. You frighten me. Sit over there.

question: Okay. I'm way over here. Is that better?
answer: It's a little better, but you still look angry.

question: How's this?
answer: Good. Good. That's nice. That's very nice. I think I'm coming out of it now. Yes. Yes. I'm definitely coming out of it. Thank you for smiling. It helped a great deal.

question: Well, you know what they say, "Smile and the world smiles with you." Heh, heh. The man should be in a straight jacket. Feeling better?
answer: Much, thank you. But I am a little lightheaded. Maybe I should eat something. Hysterics have a way of severely depleting one's blood sugar, you know.

question: They certainly do. They certainly do. Come, let me take you to lunch.
answer: That's very kind of you, Mr. Bialystock, but I ...

question: Nonsense, nonsense, my dear boy. I lowered your blood sugar, but least I could do is raise it a little. And I promise you faithfully, I won't discuss that silly scheme to make a million dollars anymore. Avanti!
answer: Thank you.

question: Je vous empris. My hat.
answer: I'll get it.

question: Murray, I'm going to lunch. I took two dollars. I know. Don't worry. You'll get it. You'll get it.
answer: I got it, Mr. Bialystock.

question: Thank you, Leo. And call me Max. You know, I don't let everybody call me Max. It's only people I really like.
answer: Okay ... Max! And you can call me Leo.

question: I already have. Come on.
answer: Oh.

question: Where would you like to eat?
answer: Well, Max, I don't know, Max. What do you think, Max?

question: Let me see ... it's such a beautiful day. Why waste it indoors. I've got it! Let's go to Coney Island! We'll lunch at the sea shore.
answer: Coney Island??

question: What's the matter, Leo? Don't you like Coney Island?
answer: I ... I love it. I haven't been there since I was a kid. But it's nearly two o'clock. I really should be getting back to Whitehall and Marks.

question: Nonsense! As far as Whitehall and Marks are concerned, you're working with Bialystock, right?
answer: Right.

question: Then stick with Bialystock! We'll have another round. What kind now, Leo?
answer: I don't know. Let's see. We've had chocolate, vanilla, banana - let's go green.

question: Two pistachios, my good man. Everybody's a big shot. Well, Leo, are you having a good time?
answer: I don't know. I think so. I feel very strange.

question: Maybe you're happy.
answer: Yes. That's it. Happy. Well, whatta ya think of that. Happy. I love it. I love it. Get set. We're coming to another turn.

question: Bloom, it can always be like this. Life can be beautiful. Let me show you. Stick with ... Bialysto-o-o-o-ckk. Money is honey. Money is honey. Money can put soft things next to your skin. Silk ... satin ... women.
answer: But if we're caught, we'll go to prison.

question: You think you're not in prison now? Living in a grey little room. Going to a grey little job. Leading a grey little life.
answer: You're right. You're absolutely right. I'm a nothing. I spend my life counting other people's money -- people I'm smarter than, better than. Where's my share? Where's Leo Bloom's share? I want, I want, I want, I want everything I've ever seen in the movies! Hey, we're going up.

question: You bet your boots, Leo. It's Bialystock and Bloom -- on the rise. Upward and onward. Say, you'll join me. Nothing can stop us.
answer: I'll do it! By God, I'll do it!

question: This is where we belong, Leo. On top of the world. Top of the world! Oiiiiiii!!!
answer: Ohhhhhhhh!!! Max, let's call it a night. It's two in the morning. I don't know what I'm reading anymore.

question: Read, read. We've got to find the worst play ever written. Hmmnn. "Gregor Samsa awoke one morning to find he had been transformed into a giant cock-a- roach." It's good!!!
answer: Wait a minute, I've read this part. I'm reading plays I read this morning. Good lord, it's morning. Let's face it, we'll never find it. Max, tomorrow's another day. Today's another day.

question: We'll never find it, eh? We'll never find it, eh? Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha. You can't smell it when it's under your nose. You can't see it when it's right before your eyes. You can't feel it when it's in your hand, when it's in your pocket.
answer: Max, what is it? What are you doing? What's happening?

question: I'll tell you what's happening. We've struck gold. Not fool's gold, but real gold. The mother lode. The mother lode. The mother of them all.
answer: You found a flop!

question: A flop, ha! That's putting it mildly. A disaster! A catastrophe! An outrage! A guaranteed-to-close- in-one-night beauty! This is freedom from want forever. This is a house in the country. This is a Rolls Royce and a Bentley. This is wine, women and song and women.
answer: "SPRINGTIME FOR HITLER, A Gay Romp with Adolph and Eva in Berchtesgarten." Fantastic!

question: It's practically a love letter to Hitler!
answer: It won't run a week!

question: Run a week? Are you kidding? This play has got to close in the first act.
answer: Who wrote it? Here it is -- 415.

question: Oh, the kraut. He's on the top floor. Apartment twenty-three.
answer: Thank you.

question: But you won't find him there. He's up on the roof with his birds. He keeps birds. Dirty, disgusting, filthy, lice-ridden birds. You used to be able to sit out on the stoop like a person. Not anymore. No sir. Birds! You get my drift?
answer: We ... uh ... get your drift. Thank you, Madam.

question: Shhh. Don't say anything to offend him. We need that play. Franz Liebkind?
answer: I vas never a member of the Nazi party. I am not responsible. I only followed orders. Who are you?

question: Mr. Liebkind, wait. You don't understand.
answer: Vhy do you persecute me? My papers are in order. I love my country. "Oh, beautiful for spacious skies, For amber vaves of grain."

question: Mr. Liebkind, wait ...
answer: "I'm a Yankee Doodle Dandy ...

question: Mr. Liebkind, relax, relax, we're not from the government. We came here to talk to you about your play.
answer: My play? You mean, "Springtime For ... " you know who?

question: Yes.
answer: Vat about it?

question: We loved it. We thought it was a masterpiece. That's why we're here. We want to produce it on Broadway.
answer: You're not, as you Americans say, dragging my leg, are you?

question: You're not, as you Americans say, dragging my leg, are you?
answer: No, not at all sir, we're quite serious. We want to produce your play. I have the contracts right here.

question: Oh joy of joys! Oh, dream of dreams! I can't believe it. Birds, birds, do you hear? Otto, Bertz, Heintz, Hans, Wolfgang, do you hear? Ve are going to clear the Fuhrer's name. Fly, fly, spread the words. "Deutchland, Deutchland, uber alles, Uber alles in der velt." "Deutchland, Deutchland ... "
answer: Mr. Liebkind, Mr. Liebkind.

question: Vat?
answer: People can hear you.

question: We go to my flat. An occasion like this calls for Schnapps. Mr. Bloom, Mr. Bialystock. Gentleman, with your permission, I would like to propose a toast to the greatest man that ever lived. Let us say his name quietly to ourselves. The walls have ears. Adolph Hitler.
answer: Sigmund Freud.

question: Max Bialystock.
answer: I vas vit him a great deal, you know.

question: With whom?
answer: Vit the Fuhrer, of course. He liked me. Out of all the household staff at Berchtesgarten, I vas his favorite. I vas the only one allowed into his chambers at bedtime.

question: No kidding?
answer: Oh, sure. I used to take him his hot milk and his opium. Achhh, those were the days. Vat good times ve had. Dinner parties vit lovely ladies and gentlemen, singing und dancing. You know, not many people knew about it, but the Fuhrer vas a terrific dancer.

question: Really, I never dreamed ...
answer: That's because you were taken in by that verdampter Allied propaganda. Such filthy lies. But nobody said a bad vord about Winston Churchill, did they? Oh no, Vin Vit Vinnie! Churchill, vit his cigars and his brandy and his rotten paintings. Couldn't even say Nazi. He would say Narzis, Narzis. Ve vere not Narzies, ve vere Nazis. But let me tell this, and you're getting it straight from the horse, Hitler vas better looking than Churchill, he vas a better dresser than Churchill, had more hair, told funnier jokes, and could dance the pants off Churchill!

question: That's exactly why we want to do this play. To show the world the true Hitler, the Hitler you knew, the Hitler you loved, the Hitler with a song in his heart. Leo, quick, the contract. Here, sign here, Franz Liebkind. And make your dream a reality.
answer: Wait. No. How do I know I can trust you? How do I know you vill present this play in the manner and spirit in vhich it vas conceived?

question: We swear it!
answer: Not good enough... Vould you be villing to take the Siegfried oath?

question: Yes. We would!
answer: Good. I will make the preparations.

question: Please to don your helmets. Please to light your candles. Please repeat after me. I solemnly swear...
answer: I solemnly swear...

question: By the sacred memory...
answer: By the sacred memory...

question: Of Siegfried...
answer: Of Siegfried...

question: Wagner...
answer: Wagner...

question: Nietzche...
answer: Nietzche...

question: Bismark...
answer: Bismark...

question: Hindenburg...
answer: Hindenburg...

question: The Graf Spee...
answer: The Graf Spee...

question: The Blue Max...
answer: The Blue Max...

question: And last, but not least, Adolph... you know who.
answer: And last, but not least, Adolph... you know who.

question: Heil you know who!
answer: Heil you know who!

question: There it is... in red and white! "Springtime For Hitler," signed, sealed and delivered. What's the matter with you?
answer: Look, I'm just not wearing this arm band. I don't care how big the deal is.

question: Okay, take it off, take it off. The Blue Gypsy.
answer: Why are we going to the Blue Gypsy?!

question: We are not going to The Blue Gypsy. I am going to The Blue Gypsy. I have a rendez-vous with a lady of some means. You see dear Bloom, phase one is complete, the play is ours. We are now entering phase two -- the raising of the money. In the days to come, you will see very little of me, for Bialystock is launching himself into little- old-lady-land. Avanti! Our play, my love. Think nothing of it, my dear. A mere trifle. A mere trifle. Did you bring your checkbook? Think nothing of it. Thank you, my dear. Edna, I swear on my life, you don't look a day over sixty-five. Clear the road! Clear the road! Heh, heh, heh. Hah, hah, hah. It's beautiful, Alma, beautiful. Oi. How's this? Money is honey, money is honey.
answer: Mrs. Sarah Catheart. She owns 50% of the profits. Mrs. Eleanor Biddlecombe. She also owns 50% of the profits. Mrs. Virginia Resnick. She also owns 50% of the profits. Mrs. Alma Wentworth. She owns 100% of the profits.

question: Leo, what if this play is a hit?
answer: Then the Department of Justice owns 100% of Bialystock and Bloom.

question: OI. I'm depressed. Leo, do me a favor. Open the safe. I want to see the money. That's better.
answer: What are you doing?

question: I'm going to buy a toy. I worked very, very hard and I think I deserve a toy.
answer: A toy? That's a toy?

question: I'll show you. Ulla, go to work.
answer: Ya, sur.

question: See, it helps the day go by. Ulla, okay. Okay. Go to desk. Answer telephone. Bialystock and Bloom. Bialystock and Bloom.
answer: Bialystock and Blum. Bialystock and Blum. Bialystock and Blum. Got dag pa dig. Bialystock and Blum.

question: Nice girl.
answer: Max, as I was saying, maybe we should go easy on the spending. I mean these offices and everything.

question: Why? Take it when you can get it! Flaunt it, baby, flaunt it!
answer: But if something should... God forbid... go wrong, at least we could give them some of their money back. It would look better in court.

question: Stop talking like that, you white mouse! Nothing's going to go wrong. As a matter of fact, today I have taken steps to insure total disaster. At two o'clock we have an appointment with none other than Roger De Bris.
answer: Roger De Bris. Roger De Bris. Oh yes, the director. Is he good... I mean bad?

question: Roger De Bris is the worst director that ever lived.
answer: Do you think he'll take the job?

question: Only if we ask him. Come on. We'd better hurry. We're late. Call chauffeur. Get car.
answer: Good. Good. We go Motel.

question: No. We go.
answer: You, Blum go Motel.

question: No. No Motel. Get car. Get car.
answer: Get car. Get car.

question: How would you like to go back to teasing hair, big mouth?
answer: Roger, do you mind if we talk a little business?

question: Please, please, that's what we're here for. Be careful, that hurt.
answer: I think this would be a marvelous opportunity for you, Roger. Up to now, you've always been associated with musicals, and...

question: Yes. Dopey show-girls in gooey gowns. Two-three-kick-turn! Turn- turn-kick-turn! It's enough to make you throw up! At last a chance to do straight drama! To deal with conflict, with inner truth. Roger De Bris presents history. Of course, I think we should add a little music. That whole third act has got to go. They're losing the war. It's too depressing. We'll have to put something in there. Aaahghhh! I see it! A line of beautiful girls, dressed as Storm Troopers, black patent leather boots, all marching together... Two-three-kick-turn! Turn-turn- kick-turn!
answer: That's genius. That's genius. Roger, I think I speak for Mr. Bloom and myself when I say that you're the only man in the world who can do justice to SPRINGTIME

question: Wait a minute. This is a very big decision. It might effect the course of my entire life. I'll have to think about it. I'll do it.
answer: Congratulations.

question: Get on the phone. Send out a casting call. Call every agent in town. I want to see everybody. Everybody.
answer: Roger, what about that one? The fat Hitler on the right?

question: I don't know. I rather fancy that one.
answer: Not bad. Not bad. What do you think, Franz?

question: Oh, this is bedlam, bedlam. We must have some order. Will all the dancing Hitlers please wait in the wings. We're only taking the singing Hitlers.
answer: Arthur Packard.

question: Hello, Arthur. Tell us something about yourself. What happened? What are you going to sing for us Arthur? Thank you. Next please.
answer: Jason Green.

question: Well, Jason, what have you been doing lately? Good. And what are you going to sing for us, Jason? Thaaank you. Thaaank you. Thaaank you. Thaank you. Thaaank you.
answer: Well, that's it.

question: Hey, man.
answer: I beg your pardon.

question: Is this where they're auditioning Boomerang?
answer: No, I'm afraid you've wandered into the wrong theatre.

question: Lorenzo Saint DuBois. But everybody calls me LSD.
answer: What have you done, LSD?

question: Six months, I'm out on probation, but it's cool now, baby.
answer: I mean in show business.

question: Oh, in show business. Well, let's put it this way, my next job will be my debut.
answer: What do you do best?

question: Hey, man, I can't do that here, that's what they put me away for.
answer: Oh, sing. Sing!

question: Hey, baby, that's where they put me, Sing-Sing. How'd you know that, you been up?
answer: Sing a song! Just sing a song!

question: That's our Hitler!
answer: Vaaaat???

question: Franz, don't you see, Hitler was a man of his time. This is a man of his time.
answer: But he has long hair!

question: Don't look at the outside, look at the inside. It's the inner Hitler we're after. The young beautiful Hitler, who danced his way to glory.
answer: I don't know. I don't know.

question: But he's so crazy, he's so sloppy, he's so... so... American!
answer: Franz, trust me. I promise I won't let you down.

question: All right, but remember, if you damage the Fuhrer's reputation, I kill you.
answer: Bite your tongue. I hope you lose your bloomers. God Forbid.

question: Gentlemen, this is a very momentous moment. Good luck. Good luck. Tonight, New York. Tomorrow, the world! No!!
answer: So much for Nutsy Fagin.

question: So much for Nutsy Fagin.
answer: Here comes the Times Drama Critic.

question: Watch closely, as Bialystock drives the last nail into the coffin. Always delighted to see the gentlemen of the press. There you are, sir. Two on the aisle, compliments of the management. It's no mistake. Enjoy the show. I'm bribing you. And if you play ball, there's a lot more where that came from. Heh, heh, heh. He'll kill us.
answer: Come on, they've started the overture. Well, Max, this is it!!! I'm sorry, I'm a little nervous.

question: Now I'll take the lead and I want you right behind me all the way! One... two... three! "By the light,
answer: "By the light, by the light,

question: "Of the silvery moon,
answer: "Of the silvery mooooon,

question: "I want to croon,
answer: "He wants to croon, he wants to croon,

question: "To my honey I'll croon,
answer: "He's gonna croon love's tune,

question: "Honeymoon,
answer: "Honeymoon, honeymoon,

question: Maybe it's not true!
answer: No way out. No way out.

question: Bloom, Bloom, maybe it's not true.
answer: No way out. No way out. What? Who?

question: Why don't we go over to the theatre and see what's really happening? After all, we've only heard from a small portion of the audience. Let's hear what the majority thinks.
answer: The majority. The majority. Yes. Let's hear from the majority. I don't want to go in.

question: No good, baby, no good. You heard my orders. Nobody retreats. Attack! Attack! Hey, man, let's stomp Switzerland!
answer: Baby, again with that baby. There must be no more babies.

question: Where's Goebbels? Where's my little Joe? He's the only cat left that still grooves me. What did you tell the people? Hey, baby, that's good! How'd we come out? Groovy!
answer: Bring down the curtain! Bring down the curtain!

question: Goebbels, you're the only one...
answer: I am the author of this play. You are the victims of a hoax. These are not my words. The Fuhrer never said baby. The Fuhrer was sweet, the Fuhrer was kind, the Fuhrer was good. NO! No! The curtain must not go up! Stop! Stop! We have been betrayed! I will return! I will returnnnnn...

question: No! No! We don't make love. Go to work. "Congratulations. It's the biggest hit on Broadway." "Congratulations. Hitler will run forever." Congratulations! Congratulations! Congratulations! Congratulations!
answer: Congratulations! Have you seen the reviews? Have you seen the lines at the box office? It's a torrent, it's an avalanche, it's the biggest hit on Broadway!

question: You lousy fruit. You've ruined me!
answer: Help! Help! He's crazy! He's going to kill me. Call the police! Call the police! Help, help, murder, murder, rape, rape!!!

question: How could this happen? I was so careful. I picked the wrong play, the wrong director, the wrong cast. Where did I go right? We forgot one important, Bloom. Adolf Hitler always drew a crowd. What are you doing?
answer: Don't try to stop me. I've made up my mind.

question: What are you doing with those books? Where are you going?
answer: I'm turning myself in. It's the only way. I'm going to cooperate with the authorities. They'll reduce my sentence and then there's time off for good behavior. And maybe I'll get a job in the prison library. So long.

question: Leo, take it easy. Relax, you're overwrought. You don't know what you're doing. You're acting out of panic... GIMME THOSE BOOKS!
answer: I never should have listened to you.

question: I never should have listened to you.
answer: Ohhhhhhhhh, how I hate you.

question: Double. Double. Double. Haaaaa! Haaaaa! Haaaaa!
answer: FAT! FAT! FAT! FAT! FAT!

question: And now ve must resume hostilities. Are you coming out from behind that desk or not?
answer: Not.

question: Cowards, miserable cringing cowards. Clinging to life like baby butterflies. Vatch, vatch and remember. Franz Liebkind vill show you how to die like a man! Soon I vill be vit mine Fuhrer, und Goering, und Goebbels, and Himmler. I'm coming boys! Boy, vhen things go wrong! I'm a failure. I'm a failure. I'm a failure.
answer: Five o'clock. Killed a whole day playing hide-and-seek with a crazy Kraut.

question: Vhere? Vhere?... oh...
answer: You crazy lunatic! What are you shooting at us for? Why don't you use this where it will do us some good? Why don't you shoot the actors? Liebkind, have I ever steered you wrong?

question: Always.
answer: Never mind. Listen. Every night people are laughing at your beloved Fuhrer. Why?

question: It's that LSD und his verdampter babies!...
answer: Here. Buy bullets. Kill. Kill them all!

question: Dynamite. Fuse cap. Fuse. Thank you. Gut. Now for the master connection. Gut. Now vhere's the other fuse?
answer: There it is.

question: Pick it up and bring it here, please.
answer: Okay.

question: Where are you going vit the light?
answer: I need it. How'm I gonna find the fuse?

question: You mean out of business. Heh, heh.
answer: Max, I...

question: What is it?
answer: Well, I... Well, it's just that... I'm sorry I called you fat, fat, fat.

question: Ahhhhhh. Leo, Leo, Leo.
answer: Plus to minus. Negative to positive. Male to...

question: Come on. Let's get going.
answer: Qviet. Qviet This is very important. Vait a minute. Vait a minute. Male to male? Male to female? Female to male? Female to female? Vait a minute. In people, male to female. But electricity is strange. It's male to male. Sehr gut. Slow fuse, please. Thank you. Now ve take the slow fuse. Tie one end to the master connection and the other ve attach to the detonator. Come, ve go to the detonator. Vait a minute. Are you sure this is slow fuse? It feels like qvick fuse. Shine your light on it. I don't know. I don't know. The markings are so similar. Qvick fuse or slow fuse? I must find out. It is critical. Let's face it. That was dumb. Boys, vhere is you? Dot vas the qvick one.

question: We assumed that.
answer: Here. You see. This is the slow fuse. It is much wider. It has more resistance, more density. Therefore, it burns slower.

question: You mean you had the slow fuse in your pocket all the time and you forgot to put it on?
answer: Yes. Amazing isn't it?

question: You stupid kraut!
answer: Vhy do you always call me kraut? Kraut is cabbage! Do ve call you hot dogs? Ve call you Yanks not franks!

question: All right. Finish the job. Let's get outta here.
answer: Und now for the final connection.

question: Wait. I'll check to see if the coast is clear. The coast is clear!
answer: Good. Get down. Goodbye, my foolish fancy. Goodbye, my misbegotten child. Goodbye, my tortured testament of twisted truths.

question: Do it! Do it!
answer: I can't. I can't do it. It's a demon. It's a gargoyle, it's a monster... but it's still my child.

question: Nothing.
answer: Here is gut... of course, of course. In electricity, it's always male to female. But with people, it's not always so. Come ve must go back.

question: Do you need us?
answer: Of course I need you. It's dark in there.
